Paces nervously while waiting for Bruce and questions Burns about potential tricks.
Takes a drink from the flask when nervous but quickly resumes attention to the situation.
Frantically questions Louie about Mrs. Baldwin's whereabouts, showing urgency and concern but some emotional distress.
Expresses concern repeatedly for the old lady's well-being, presses for information.
Shows signs of distress and worry (moaning, paralyzed), sinks into a chair overwhelmed by the situation.
Quickly questions Louie about the whereabouts and condition of the old lady, showing alertness and concern.
Appears paralyzed and sinks into a chair when Louie implies the old lady might be harmed or killed, showing emotional overwhelm.
Expresses deep guilt and worry about facing Bruce after a tragedy, showing emotional vulnerability.
Calls out Burns as a 'murderer' in a moment of frustration, indicating direct and harsh communication.
Immediately takes initiative to find out details and reach out (calls Louie, then phone contacts), showing care and responsibility.
Patiently and persistently calls multiple hospitals to find information about an old lady involved in an auto accident.
Refers to herself professionally when calling hospitals, showing sincerity and earnestness in her inquiry.
Interrupts or allows others to drown her out on the phone without visible frustration or rudeness in the excerpt.
Initiates multiple phone calls, methodically gathers information by contacting various hospital operators, confidently navigates confusing and obstructive dialogue.
Interrupts and sharply tells Burns to shut up while he is upset and shouting.
Calmly tells Burns to shut up amid his frantic yelling, then efficiently makes a phone call asking 'You sure? Nobody?'
Struggles and pleads hysterically about something happening to her mother-in-law, tries to convince others honestly.
Tries to push past Sheriff and deputies, demands they let her go while being restrained.
Denies knowledge and tries to explain the situation sincerely to the authorities.
Attempts to unlock and enter the morgue despite being told not to, takes initiative in seeking information about an accident.
Struggles and protests loudly when detained by the sheriff and deputies, showing assertiveness but little strategic calmness.
Breaks loose from the deputies and retreats into the room, showing ability to physically escape but not necessarily to de-escalate or handle the situation diplomatically.
Claims ignorance and offers to have someone accompany her, attempting to negotiate and demonstrate openness, suggesting some quick thinking.
Appears somewhat flustered and hysterical in front of the authorities, which might undermine her perceived skillfulness and confidence.
Struggles fiercely against deputies trying to take her away, fights back physically despite odds.
Protects herself by picking up a gun and tries to manage the situation calmly by tossing the gun to Walter, indicating a sense of responsibility and composure.
Firmly asserts her right to carry a gun, showing self-assuredness but also a degree of defensiveness.
Faces suspicion and accusations from others (e.g., Murphy's bitter comment, others calling her rotten), but continues to interact without hostility, showing resilience and tolerance.
Refers to the bag of marshmallows humorously amid tension.
Denies ownership of desk to protect property in front of authority.
Leaps forward to greet her mother warmly with a hug, expresses concern by asking if she is all right.
Leaps forward immediately to greet her mother with concern and affection.
Calms her indignant mother by saying 'Please, Mother, he's just crazy!'
Calmly tries to defuse a tense situation by telling her mother 'Please, Mother, he's just crazy!'
Calmly assures others that the man hiding is harmless and cannot hurt anyone.
Calmly asserts that the man in the desk is harmless and that they have his gun, attempting to deescalate the situation.
Does not prevent the chaos that ensues, including Mrs. Baldwin panicking and rushing out, despite her calming words.
Stands handcuffed with Burns after being apprehended by police, remaining composed.
Is arrested alongside Burns in a situation involving aiding an escaped criminal.
Questions Pinkus upon his unexpected delivery of the reprieve, indicating awareness and engagement in the unfolding drama.
Seizes Pinkus to question him, advocates for letting him speak instead of being thrown out.
Accuses officials of hanging an innocent man to win an election, showing concern for justice.
Confronts the Mayor with a harsh accusation, calls him willing to kill his mother to get elected.
Seizes Pinkus, questions him assertively, commands officers to listen and release Pinkus, challenges the mayor and sheriff's narrative firmly.
Calls out the mayor's willingness to kill to win an election, indicating insight and boldness.
Interrupts and manages chaotic situation effectively by keeping control and demanding information.
Urges the mayor and Burns to quit politics humorously after releasing the prisoners.
Jokes about asking for the mayor's impeachment and arrest.
Makes a sarcastic, confident remark to the Mayor and Burns about their political career and potential consequences, showing quick wit and assuredness in a tense situation.
Sharing a warm smile and nostalgic laughter with Burns about past adventures and challenges they've faced together.
Acknowledges shared fault in their complicated relationship with Burns, showing acceptance and sincerity.
Engages in a tense, vulnerable coin toss to decide whether to stay or leave, indicating openness and honesty with Burns.
Almost emotionally breaks but remains composed, showing emotional sincerity and vulnerability.
Considers taking the later train to write the story and engage with her work, showing dedication.
Flips a coin to decide whether to stay and write the story or leave, indicating some indecision but also a pragmatic approach to decision-making.
States 'What's the difference? I'm going to write that story -- and you know it!' showing strong resolve and confidence in her professional capabilities.
Expresses uncertainty saying 'I don't know what to do,' revealing momentary indecision and emotional conflict.
Furiously rejects Burns' attempt to embrace her, telling him not to touch her.
Reluctantly admits her devotion to newspaper work despite personal struggles.
Grimly thanks Burns for praise but does not return enthusiasm openly.
Chooses not to leave the newspaper world despite prior plans, indicating complexity in relationships.
Types furiously and produces a major news story that saves Earl Williams and exposes political wrongdoing, earning enthusiastic praise from Burns.
Correctly anticipates and intercepts the communication to Bruce by wiring him that she won't be coming, demonstrating forethought and strategic planning.
Displays grim gratitude rather than enthusiasm when praised, perhaps indicating emotional strain but does not diminish her clear professional skill.
Expresses inability to provide affection and peace to Bruce, acknowledges personal limitations.
Engages in playful, affectionate banter with Walter about marriage and romance.
Rejects the idea of returning to Walter in a reconciliatory but firm manner.
Acknowledges her limitations as a 'cheap reporter' who would give up her soul for a story, reflecting self-awareness about her professional identity.
Insists that her previous attempt at marriage with Walter was no good, showing realism and decisiveness about her personal and professional boundaries.
Expresses skepticism about romance and idealized notions by sarcastically referencing problematic honeymoons, demonstrating critical thinking.
Reacting with surprise and enthusiasm to Walter's suggestion of going to Niagara Falls, showing openness to change but also impulsiveness.
Questioning what Walter would do if they had a daughter, showing an ability to challenge and critically discuss future plans.
Resists being rushed into marriage, expresses fear but stands up to threat.
Sarcastically warns Judge not to believe Burns' promises.
Expresses skepticism and refuses to be rushed into a decision about marriage despite pressure.
Is physically intimidated by Louie sticking a gun in her ribs and shows fear.
Maintains her verbal defiance despite being scared and physically threatened.
Teases Judge and Burns during the ceremony with playful skepticism.
Accepts Burns' use of Bruce's ring despite initial protest, showing flexibility and trust.
Expresses doubt about the future with Burns, calling herself a fool but acknowledging reality.
Mocks Burns' promise by saying 'You're not fooling anybody' confidently.
Makes witty, sharp remarks during the wedding vows, showing mental agility.
Takes the ring begrudgingly, aware of the complications but proceeds anyway.
Admits 'I'm just a fool' after the ceremony, showing self-doubt.
Confronts Walter Burns about counterfeit money and pursues him aggressively, showing anger and betrayal.
Stops cold upon seeing the newspaper headline about counterfeit money, immediately connects it to Walter's actions, showing alertness and quick inference.
Runs after Walter, throws her bag to smash glass to block him, showing decisiveness and willingness to act under pressure.
Confronts Walter aggressively but does not pause to hear explanation, possibly indicating impulsiveness.
